Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Alternative Pathways for Biofuel formation from Furfuryl alcohol over Heterogeneous Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Kim (1546647)
This is an exploratory, proof-of-concept study aimed primarily at reacting furfuryl alcohol (a major intermediate product of biomass refining) directly to hydrocarbon molecules containing nine to twenty carbon atoms suitable for use as transportation fuels, specifically diesel and jet fuel. Traditional processing is based on catalysis by sulfuric acid. This proposal seeks to demonstrate better performance and product selectivity utilizing supported catalysts while also providing opportunities for improved process efficiency, reduced waste, and a greener environmental footprint.

Biomass conversion to useful products is challenged by the broad range of intermediate products produced from the intial pyrolysis of the biomass feedstock together with downstream conversion of the intermediates selectively to high-value fuel and chemical products. Catalysis offers opportunities for facilitating the downstream reactions, but reaction selectivity to desired products is still a challenge and catalyst deactivation is common. This project will provide a direct route for reacting a major intermediate product of biomass refining - furfuryl alcohol - directly to C9-C20 alkanes suitable for transportation fuels, while also providing insight into the mechanism of both the oligomerization reaction and the monomer reaction to cyclopentanone, another commercially important product. The proposal is based on the hypothesis that selectivity toward the targeted alkanes can be markedly improved with respect to the homogeneous acid-catalyzed reaction by using supported heterogeneous catalysts with tunable acidic and basic sites combined with optimized reaction conditions. To this end, the study will screen a broad space of catalyst formulations, reactor design, and operating conditions to enhance C9-C20 product efficiency.

The proposed work addresses an important area of research related to energy independence and renewable resources in the form of cellulosic biomass, with potential to produce economic routes to diesel and jet fuel. In parallel, the investigator will also explore conversion of furfuryl alcohol directly to cyclopentanone, a versatile chemical feedstock. Both studies will be conducted in collaboration with Brookhaven National Laboratory to obtain fundamental scientific understanding of relevance to a broad range of catalytic reactions. From an educational standpoint, the project will provide broad catalyst training to one graduate student and an undergraduate researcher, as well as expanding educational outreach programs the investigator has previously established with high school students.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemicals and fuels derived from lignocellulosic biomass are currently attracting great attention and biomass derived furan derivatives, such as Furfuryl alcohol, will serve as renewable source of carbon containing molecules. The proposed exploratory results brought from fundamental scientific molecular (alcohol) reaction to biomass industry application for biofuel and chemical production. During the proposal period, comprehensive studies using different analytical (GC and GC/MS) and spectroscopic (FTIR and Raman) methods on the FA oligomerization over the bulk metal oxide catalysts (e.g., WO3, MoO3, Al2O3, ZrO2, TiO2, Nb2O5, and SiO2) were carried out and investigated to prove the feasibility of using the catalysts under liquid phase reaction conditions. Among the tested catalysts, WO3 and MoO3 catalysts showed higher catalytic activity than others. The results also provided that difurfuryl ether and 5-Furfuryl-furfuryl alcohol dimers were the dominant products among the observed five dimers which were very similar to homogeneous catalysis results. Using IR and Raman spectroscopic techniques, we asserted that both conjugated diene and diketone structures can be co-existed in the metal oxide catalyzed FA oligomers. Based on the current catalyst recycle test, we can suggest that metal oxide catalysts are an alternative to current homogeneous catalysts (sulfuric acid) for the FA oligomerization reaction. In addition to the FA oligomerization reaction, we investigated the unreacted FA monomer extraction and separation processes to increase conversion and reduce chemical wastes. We reported that deionized water as a green solvent could be used efficiently for the FA monomer extraction from acid catalyzed FA products, with a high extractability. We also found that unreacted FA monomer and trace amounts of oligomers can be also separated from aqueous solution using the salting-out method. After two-step processes (extraction and separation), we recovered ~84% unreacted FA monomer.

In addition to the research achievements, it was intended that this EAGER proposal research project will leverage the educational and outreach activities for high school to graduate students who are interested in catalysis research. The PI actively involved the education of underrepresented minorities and female students. Trained high school to graduate students (especially women and minorities) were encouraged to participate at regional and national catalysis conferences. Results from proposed research were used in the currently developed catalysis class and published in peer reviewed journals.

In summary, the proposed research provided the feasibility of using metal oxide catalysts for the FA oligomerization reaction. The PI group have been also investing catalyst loading, surface area, and phase effect on the FA conversion and products’ selectivity. The obtained results can be applied to other alcohol dehydration reaction such as aromatic alcohol. (transformative research) This proposed research generated several preliminary data and the PI submitted the NSF proposal recently. Awarded NSF grants supported 2 undergraduate and 1 graduate student. After completion of the proposal, the collected data were published in ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering (2016, 4 (8),4084–4088) (Cover story)

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2016
Modified by: Tae Jin Kim
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Chemicals and fuels derived from lignocellulosic biomass are currently attracting great attention and biomass derived furan derivatives, such as Furfuryl alcohol, will serve as renewable source of carbon containing molecules. The proposed exploratory results brought from fundamental scientific molecular (alcohol) reaction to biomass industry application for biofuel and chemical production. During the proposal period, comprehensive studies using different analytical (GC and GC/MS) and spectroscopic (FTIR and Raman) methods on the FA oligomerization over the bulk metal oxide catalysts (e.g., WO3, MoO3, Al2O3, ZrO2, TiO2, Nb2O5, and SiO2) were carried out and investigated to prove the feasibility of using the catalysts under liquid phase reaction conditions. Among the tested catalysts, WO3 and MoO3 catalysts showed higher catalytic activity than others. The results also provided that difurfuryl ether and 5-Furfuryl-furfuryl alcohol dimers were the dominant products among the observed five dimers which were very similar to homogeneous catalysis results. Based on the current catalyst recycle test, we can suggest that metal oxide catalysts are an alternative to current homogeneous catalysts (sulfuric acid) for the FA oligomerization reaction. In addition to the research achievements, it was intended that this EAGER proposal research project will leverage the educational and outreach activities for high school to graduate students who are interested in catalysis research. The PI actively involved the education of underrepresented minorities and female students. Trained high school to graduate students (especially women and minorities) were encouraged to participate at regional and national catalysis conferences. In summary, the proposed research provided the feasibility of using metal oxide catalysts for the FA oligomerization reaction. The PI group have been also investing catalyst loading, surface area, and phase effect on the FA conversion and products? selectivity. The obtained results can be applied to other alcohol dehydration reaction such as aromatic alcohol. (transformative research) This proposed research generated several preliminary data and the PI submitted the NSF proposal recently. Awarded NSF grants supported 2 undergraduate and 1 graduate student.
